\begin{abstract}
Recent hydrodynamical simulations of supernova (SN) evolution have
highlighted the importance of a thorough control over microscopic
physics responsible for such internal processes as neutrino heating. In
particular, it has been suggested that modifications to the
neutrino-nucleon elastic cross section can potentially play a crucial
role in producing successful supernova explosions. One possible source
of such corrections can be found in a nonzero value for the nucleon's
strange helicity content $\Delta s$. In the present analysis, however, we show
that theoretical and experimental progress over the past decade has suggested
a comparatively small magnitude for $\Delta s$, such that its sole effect
is not sufficient to provide the physics leading to supernova explosions.

\end{abstract}

\section{Introduction/SNe Physics}
\label{sec:intro}



As standard candles for cosmic distance calibrations \citep{Riess:1998cb}, supernova
(SN) explosions play a central role in cosmology and astrophysics. All the more,
supernovae (SNe) have for many decades been recognized as the sites and means of populating
the galaxies with heavier elements via stellar nucleosynthesis \citep{Burbidge:1957vc}.
Despite these facts, as well as considerable recent progress \citep{Janka:2012wk}, the detailed
picture of basic physics responsible for these events remains murky.


Pivotal to the dynamics leading to the ejection of material associated with
SNe is the evolution of the bounce shock produced by the collapse of a massive
star's Fe core to proto-neutron star \citep{Janka:2012wk, Murphy:2008dw}. Due to
dissipative effects originating in nuclear dissociation and neutrino emission, however,
the advancing shock tends to stall in numerical simulations, leading to the
problem of identifying the physics that re-energizes the outwardly moving front.
Since the early work of \citet{Bethe:1984ux}, the conventional explanation is
that delayed neutrinos reheat the post-shock region of the SN, reinvigorating
the shock front's advance \citep{Burrows:2012yk}. This picture has placed a considerable
premium upon controlling the various physics effects \citep{Horowitz:2001xf} that go into the
neutrino-nucleon interactions inherent to the ``delayed-neutrino mechanism.''


This is especially true in the vicinity of the so-called gain radius ---
the locus where cooling from neutrino emission is in approximate equilibrium with
the corresponding heating due to neutrino absorption \citep{Burrows:2012yk}. As such, even
incremental modifications to the neutrino-nucleon cross section such as might
follow from corrections to the nucleon's flavor structure could in principle
alter the explosive evolution of SNe. Effects of this kind might then in turn
play a decisive role in numerical simulations that successfully produce SN
explosions.


The importance of such considerations was brought to the fore by the recent
publication of \citet{Melson:2015spa}, which studied the impact of a
large magnitude nucleon strange helicity $\Delta s = -0.2$ in a simulated
core-collapse SN originating from a $20\ M_\odot$ progenitor star. As described
in greater detail below, this sizable effect constitutes a $\sim$15$\%$ reduction
in the strength of the neutrino's axial coupling to the neutron, leading to
the diminution of neutron opacities to neutrinos relative to a calculation
using $\Delta s = 0$. This crucial assumption, which we investigate in
detail in the following sections, led to the successful explosion of the SN
$\sim$300~$ms$ after shock bounce in \citet {Melson:2015spa} relative to the
$\Delta s = 0$ case, for which no explosive behavior was obtained.



The remainder of the paper is as follows: we briefly describe the basic formalism
by which $\Delta s$ enters the neutrino-nucleon cross section in Section~\ref{sec:neutrino},
and discuss the current knowledge of $\Delta s$ in Section~\ref{sec:status}. Separate focus is
given to results from experiment (Section~\ref{ssec:exp}) and theory (Section~\ref{ssec:theory}).
A short summary and conclusion are contained in Section~\ref{sec:conc}.

\section{Status of $\Delta${\tiny s}}
\label{sec:status}



Assuming it to be the sole correction to the $\nu-N$ cross section of Equation~\ref{eq:cross}
as in \citet{Melson:2015spa}, the magnitude of $\Delta s$ used to successfully obtain an
exploding SN is at odds with the latest hadron structure calculations and measurements.
Citing the lower bound of the 2002 analysis by \citet{Horowitz:2001xf}, which took

Such a sizable value is highly excluded by global analyses of the world's high
energy data \citep{Lai:2007dq,Martin:2009iq}. We obtain this by performing systematic scans
of the parameter space of the model in \citet{Hobbs:2014lea} and admitting for

tolerated by the model for $\Delta s = -0.2$ occurs for $xS^+ = 0.062$,
the mean of the full set corresponds to $xS^+ = 0.1$. In either case
this far exceeds the range determined by global analyses of DIS data such as the
dedicated CTEQ strangeness study of \citet{Lai:2007dq}, which found the $90\%$ limit
$0.018 \le xS^+ \le 0.04$ indicated by the green band in Figure~\ref{fig:scan}.
Similarly, a simple estimate using the fitted distributions of MSTW at
the QCD evolution starting scale $Q^2_0 = 1$ GeV$^2$ leads to the comparable
$68\%$ range $0.017 \lesssim xS^+ \lesssim 0.033$ \citep{Martin:2009iq}.




As a further demonstration, we consider a particular model taken from the
space plotted in Figure~\ref{fig:scan}, and use it to compute the unpolarized
quark PDF combination $x[s(x) + \bar{s}(x)]$. This has been measured by
various experimental collaborations, including HERMES \citep{Airapetian:2013zaw},
and we compare a model prediction associated with $\Delta s = -0.2$ with

as the dot-dashed curve egregiously overhangs the experimental data
obtained via kaon production in semi-inclusive DIS.




A general and robustly motivated light-front model is therefore difficult
to reconcile with large strange quark helicities without simultaneously predicting
implausibly large values for the total strange momentum $xS^+$ and $x$-dependent
distribution $x[s(x) + \bar{s}(x)]$. This finding is in step with the comparatively
small magnitudes of $\Delta s$ obtained in the most well-supported theoretical
calculations, as well as the minimal strangeness permitted by global analyses of high
energy data.

\section{Conclusion}
\label{sec:conc}




While slight ambiguity remains as to whether $\Delta s \neq 0$, significant improvements
in the last decade on the dual fronts of experimental measurement and theory
have strongly excluded the large magnitudes $\Delta s \sim -0.2$ barely allowed at the
lower reaches of the earliest analyses. As demonstrated above and summarized in
Figure~\ref{fig:bar}, more recent experiments
suggest $\Delta s \gtrsim -0.1$, whereas theoretical analyses impose 
$\Delta s \gtrsim -0.04$. Lattice and Bag Model-based calculations especially prefer still
smaller strange helicity magnitudes, $\Delta s \sim -0.02$ --- fully an
order-of-magnitude shallower than the critical value assumed in the
simulations of \citet{Melson:2015spa}.

We therefore conclude that, while the nucleon's strange spin is an important
consideration in the microphysics of SN simulations, it cannot contribute at the high level assumed
in, {\it e.g.}, \citet{Melson:2015spa}; by extension, $\Delta s$ cannot represent the single, decisive effect
generative of SN explosions. We urge the continued exploration of other
potential mechanisms, which may enter at the microscopic level of the
relevant nuclear physics or in the form of heretofore unexplored dynamical effects in the
macroscopic structure of core-collapse SNe themselves.
